questions.text: True statement regarding KF ring: Seen in all patients with neurological involvement Is pathognomonic for Wilson’s disease Resolves with treatment Seen in all patients with hepatic involvement Starts first in superior and inferior quadrant Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, 3 and 5 only Kayser–Fleischer rings are dark rings that appear to encircle the iris of the eye. They are due to copper deposition in part of the Descemet's membrane as a result of liver diseases. The rings , which consist of copper deposits where the cornea meets the sclera, in Descemet's membrane , first appear as a crescent at the top of the cornea. Eventually, a second crescent forms below, at the " six o'clock position ", and ultimately completely encircles the cornea. Kayser–Fleischer rings are seen in most of the patients with neurologic involvement from Wilson However, it may not be seen in approximately 5% of these patients. They are present in only 50% of the patients with isolated hepatic involvement and in pre-symptomatic patients. Kayser–Fleischer rings may be absent in patients with fulminant disease and in most children. The combination of neurological symptoms, a low blood ceruloplasmin level and KF rings is diagnostic of Wilson's disease.

Highyeild:

Kayser–Fleischer rings are caused by deposition of excess copper on the inner surface of the cornea in the Descemet membrane extending to the trabecular meshwork. Copper is deposited as a granular complex with sulfur which gives a ring its characteristic color. It is to be noted that copper is present throughout the cornea, however, due to fluid streaming, copper tends to accumulate superiorly and inferiorly, before involving the iris circumferentially. Copper can also be deposited in the lens in the anterior and posterior capsule causing sunflower cataracts which have radiating centrifugal extensions. Kayser–Fleischer rings typically disappear with treatment and reappear with disease progression. When present, it is a useful clinical sign to monitor treatment compliance. The rings disappear with chelation therapy over three to five years in up to 80% of patients.

Extraedge:

Other causes of KF rings are:- cholestasis (obstruction of the bile ducts), Primary biliary cirrhosis cryptogenic cirrhosis(cirrhosis in which no cause can be identified). Deposition of excess copper in the basal ganglia in the brain leads to the neurologic and psychiatric manifestations of Wilson disease.

questions.text: True regarding POAG. Abnormality of trabecular meshwork is seen on gonioscopy First degree relatives have more chances of developing steroid induced glaucoma Dilatation of pupil is associated with exacerbation of IOP First degree relatives are at 1% increased risk of POAG Visual field defect can exist with normal C:D ratio Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2 and 5 only POAG is characterized by: Increased intraocular pressure on more than one occasion , and/or Circadian variation in IOP of >8 mmHg , OR Asymmetry in IOP > 5 mmHg between both eyes

Highyeild:

Optic nerve head changes suggestive of glaucomatous damage also occur. These may include one or more of the following changes: Cup-disc (C:D) ratio > 0.5 (Normal 0.3) Asymmetry in C:D ratio >0.2 between both eyes. notching or pallor of the neuro retinal rim (NRR) Disc haemorrhages . Visual field changes . Defects in the retinal nerve fibre A diagnosis of POAG can be made if at least 2 of the first 3 criteria mentioned are met. In patients diagnosed with POAG with normal cup-disc ratio and raised IOP, the visual field defects may occur due to damage to the retinal nerve fibre layer.

Extraedge:

Risk factors: The higher the IOP , the greater the likelihood of glaucoma Myopia is associated with an increased incidence of POAG There is 10% increased risk of POAG in siblings and 4% increased risk in children of patients with POAG Patients with POAG and their offspring and siblings are more likely steroid responders e., they respond to 6 weeks topical steroid therapy with a significant rise of IOP. Note: Inability to visualize trabecular meshwork on gonioscopy indicates primary angle-closure glaucoma.

questions.text: How to differentiate the causes of a dilated pupil? 1% Phenylephrine 1% Pilocarpine 0.25% Pilocarpine 4% Cocaine Epinephrine Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2 and 3 only Conditions with fixed dilated pupils include:- 3rd nerve palsy, Uncal herniation (Hutchinson pupil), Angle closure glaucoma, Adie Pupil, etc. 1% pilocarpine is the most appropriate answer. It will constrict in 3rd nerve palsy and have no effect in pharmacological blockade. 25% pilocarpine will also help in differentiating the Adie pupil.

Highyeild:

Argyll Robertson Pupil AR Pupils are small (miosis), irregular in outline and have light near dissociation. They react poorly to light but very well to near reflex. AR Pupils are usually bilateral and symmetrical . Vision grossly intact. Causes of Optic Neuritis:- Marcus Gunn pupil is seen In optic neuritis. It is also common in retrobulbar optic neuritis due to multiple sclerosis but only for 3-4 weeks. Infection (e.g. syphilis, Lyme disease, herpes zoster), Autoimmune disorders (e.g. lupus, neurosarcoidosis, neuromyelitis optica), Inflammatory bowel disease, Drug induced (e.g.chloramphenicol, ethambutol, Isoniazid, streptomycin, quinine, penicillamine, Aminosalicylic acid, phenothiazine, phenylbutazone), Vitamin B12 deficiency Diabetes Mellitus

Extraedge:

Mydriasis results from paralysis of the parasympathetic fibers, either at their origin from the pretectal nuclei and the EW nucleus in the midbrain , during the course with the III C.N or at the ciliary ganglion at the orbit. Most commonly such lesions are:- due to vascular accidents in the midbrain , tentorial herniation (due to cerebral space occupying lesions) or aneurysms of the carotid artery
